newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada Chretien sees "balanced" budget by 1998/99.
newsitem.headline: Canada Chretien sees "balanced" budget by 1998/99.

text.p: Canadian Prime Minister Jean Chretien said on Tuesday the federal government would no longer be borrowing any new money in the financial markets by 1998/99, which, he asserted, would mean a balanced budget by international standards.

"The OECD (Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development) measures deficits on a national accounts or borrowing requirements basis. By this measurement -- the same measurement as is used in the United States, France, Germany, Great Britain, Italy -- our budget in 1998/99 will be balanced," Chretien said in a speech in Montreal.
Canadian Finance Minister Paul Martin has forecast a deficit of C$9 billion in fiscal 1998/99 (April-March), but a zero borrowing requirement for that year.
In his speech, Chretien said that by getting Canada's fiscal house in order his government had created an investment climate with low interest rates and low inflation.
He said that should give investors the confidence they need to create jobs and get a good return for their money.
Chretien appealed to potential investors to help Montreal, Canada's second largest city, back on its feet economically.
He said Montreal has always been a symbol of Canada at home and abroad, but it is suffering economically because of a flight of businesses and investment.
"Today...Montreal is in trouble. There is too much unemployment, too much poverty. When Montreal is in trouble, the province of Quebec is in trouble and so is all of Canada," Chretien said.
The threat of another referendum on Quebec separation soon after the next provincial election "is not conducive to maintaining or attracting investment to Montreal today."
Quebec's separatist government has said it intends to hold another referendum on sovereignty, but not until after the next provincial election, which could be held as late as 1998.
